{{BLP IMDb refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox person |image =Kym Whitley by Gage Skidmore.jpg |imagesize =220px |caption=Whitley at the Comic Con in San Diego, 2011. |name =Kym Whitley |birth_name = Kym Elizabeth Whitley |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1961|7|21}} |birth_place = [[Shaker Heights, Ohio|Shaker Heights]], [[Ohio]], U.S. |education = [[Shaker Heights High School]]
[[Fisk University]] |occupation = Comedian, Actress |yearsactive = 1992–present |spouse = 1 |children = 1 |URL = http://www.kymwhitley.org }} '''Kym Elizabeth Whitley''' (born July 21, 1961) is an [[United States|American]] comedian and actress. She is best known for her roles on television sitcoms, such as ''[[Animal Practice]]'', ''[[The Boondocks (TV series)|The Boondocks]]'', ''[[Young & Hungry]]'' and ''[[The Parkers]]''. Whitley was nominated for a 2004 BET Comedy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Box Office Movie for her role as Ormandy in the 2003 comedy film ''[[Deliver Us From Eva]]''. ==Personal life== Born in Shaker Heights, Ohio to Kaysonia (1936-2011) and William Whitley, Whitley has two older brothers. She attended [[Shaker Heights High School]] (graduating in 1979) and [[Fisk University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee. She is member of the Alpha Beta chapter of the [[Delta Sigma Theta]] sorority. In January 2011, Whitley adopted a son.[http://gma.yahoo.com/blogs/abc-blogs/dont-feed-t-shirts-calm-parents-allergic-kids-100406887--abc-news-health.html 'Don't Feed Me' T-Shirts Calm Parents of Allergic Kids] (March 19, 2013) ''ABC News, ABC Blogs''. Accessed 2013-03-19.[http://www.blackcelebkids.com/2011/02/28/kym-whitley-is-a-new-mom/ 'Kym Whitley is a New Mom'] (February 28, 2011) "Black Celebrity Kids". Accessed 2013-03-19. ==Career== In 1989, Whitley got her big break starring in Shelly Garrett's popular play ''[[Beauty Shop]]'', which started in Los Angeles then later traveled across the U.S. Whitley's major acting roles include ''[[My Brother and Me]]'' and ''[[Sparks (television)|Sparks]]''. She made guest appearances on several television sitcoms, including ''[[The Parent 'Hood]]'', ''[[Married... with Children]]'', ''[[Moesha]]'', ''[[That's So Raven]]'', ''[[The Parkers]]'' and ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]''. She also hosted the short-lived BET show ''Oh Drama'' (2000). Whitley also had a small role in ''[[Next Friday]]'' as Craig's aunt Suga. She was one of the group called "The Adults", who were adult cast members in the earlier seasons of ''[[All That]]''. In the early spring of 2010, Whitley was a co-host with R&B musician [[Brian McKnight]] on the short-lived talk show ''The Brian McKnight Show''. From 2012 to 2013, Whitley had a recurring role on the [[BET]] comedy ''[[Let's Stay Together (TV series)|Let's Stay Together]]'' as Charmaine Wax. Kym's [[Television documentary|docu-series]] entitled ''[[Raising Whitley]]'' on the Oprah Winfrey network (OWN) premiered on April 20, 2013 with a total of 1.2 million viewers, making it the fifth most-widely viewed premiere in the history of the network.[http://gma.yahoo.com/blogs/abc-blogs/dont-feed-t-shirts-calm-parents-allergic-kids-100406887--abc-news-health.html {{"'}}Don't Feed Me' T-Shirts Calm Parents of Allergic Kids"] (March 19, 2013) ''ABC News, ABC Blogs''. Accessed 2013-03-19. OWN ordered a second season, which premiered on January 4, 2014. Kym created the "Don't Feed Me" T-shirt with her friend [[Rodney Van Johnson]]. The shirts alert caregivers to the allergies of the children wearing them.{{cite web|url=http://www.kymwhitley.org|title=Joshua's World|website=Kymwhitley.org|accessdate=13 October 2017}} == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film !
